repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Adds support for opening a new tabpage and retrieving a handle to it, optionally entering/not entering the new tabpage.

WIP and does not quite work yet

It works when switching to the tabpage, but if `enter=false` then it's super broken so I need to look at my changes in win_new_tabpage and maybe just extract some parts of it instead of changing it.

Not sure if this is wanted, but it's a bit more intuitive than using `vim.cmd.tabnew()` then `vim.api.nvim_get_current_tabpage()` imo, especially because of the option to stay in the current tabpage.

comment_data.body:
- We almost always want to accept `opts` and return `Dict`, unless we are 100% certain we won't need to expand the features in the future (which is usually wrong).
- But in this case the returned value is a tabpage handle which (1) already represents an object, and (2) is symmetric with `nvim_open_win`.  So it's probably acceptable to return `Tabpage`.
- For `opts` (or `config`?) I could imagine an arg that controls which tabpage to open next to (like `:[count]tabnew`).

```suggestion
Tabpage nvim_open_tabpage(Buffer buffer, Boolean enter, Dict opts, Error *err)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14,6 +16,27 @@
 # include "api/tabpage.c.generated.h"
 #endif
 
+/// Opens a new tabpage with a single window
+///
+/// @param buffer   Buffer handle, or 0 for current buffer
+/// @param enter    Boolean, whether to enter the new tabpage
+/// @param[out] err Error details, if any
+/// @return Handle to newly created tabpage
+Tabpage nvim_open_tabpage(Buffer buffer, Boolean enter, Error *err)

comment_data.body: The need for `enter` here is a sign that this API is more than just a wrapper, it's actually achieving new functionality. So that's a signal that the API is probably justified.

Yes, since this would allow creating a new tabpage without entering it. Not sure if there's already a way to do that via Lua though, or if there's really even a use case for it.

I think that functionality is not fully working yet though from my comment above. I'll have to try this branch out again and see what the status is.

Good to know, I'll remember that in the future. I'll update this and add an opts dict parameter. I think the `after` idea mirroring `[count]tabnew` should be trivial because it's handled by `win_new_tabpage`, so maybe I'll add that in as well.

> is symmetric with nvim_open_win

Agreed, this was my logic for returning a tabpage handle.

re: whether this API is wanted

This was largely an experiment and I don't have a real use case for it, so no worries if it's not wanted.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14,6 +16,27 @@
 # include "api/tabpage.c.generated.h"
 #endif
 
+/// Opens a new tabpage with a single window
+///
+/// @param buffer   Buffer handle, or 0 for current buffer
+/// @param enter    Boolean, whether to enter the new tabpage
+/// @param[out] err Error details, if any
+/// @return Handle to newly created tabpage
+Tabpage nvim_open_tabpage(Buffer buffer, Boolean enter, Error *err)

comment_data.body:
Autocommands from `win_new_tabpage`, `win_set_buf` have to be considered here:

- `tp` may have been immediately freed (even `tp->handle` isn't valid in that case).
- `buf` may have been immediately freed.
- `tp->tp_firstwin` may be wrong if `win_new_tabpage` autocommands enter the tabpage and mess with the layout.

The `!enter` handling in this function will need a more scrutinous review later.

For example, the window layout is corrupted with `!enter`, as this code has a number of assumptions that we're already in the new tabpage (e.g: `win_alloc_firstwin` overwrites the `topframe`, `firstwin` is changed, etc.).
With `!enter`, these autocommands won't fire within the context of the new tabpage, which maybe they should. Also, they could free `old_curwin`.
is the todo still open? looks like there is some handling  below
Yep, forgot to remove the comment. Thanks!

comment_regular_data.body:
> Not sure if this is wanted

please allow me to add my thoughts here. it's definitely wanted for a user like me, i have some related uses that can be replaced with this new api:
* `:tab sb bufnr` -> `nvim_open_tabpage(bufnr)`
* `:tabedit nvim_buf_get_name(bufnr)` -> `nvim_open_tabpage(bufnr)`
* `:tabedit new_name` -> `nvim_open_tabpage(fn.bufadd(new_name))`

I've added the "after" option and dict argument, and another test for it.

I'm not entirely sure why I need to add 1 to the tabpage index since `tabpage_index()` already returns a value, but it works...
I may still need to look into this more, but tests are passing and there's interest so figured I'd mark as ready for review.

These are great, thank you! Gonna mark this as draft again and keep working. No rush at all :)

After doing some testing (haven't worked on this branch in a little bit before today) I think I ran into a couple of those issues myself.

@seandewar 's comments mentioned some important edge cases. I don't see `bdelete` or `bwipeout` in the tests. Do we have test coverage for "evil" autocmds that delete the window/tabpage during the event?

> @seandewar 's comments mentioned some important edge cases. I don't see `bdelete` or `bwipeout` in the tests. Do we have test coverage for "evil" autocmds that delete the window/tabpage during the event?

There are checks in the code, but no coverage for that specifically - what should I check for? Just ensuring nvim doesn't crash or claim windows/tabs exist that don't?
Thank you, I'll get these fixed soon. Sorry about that, it's been a bit since I worked on this PR.

somewhat-related question: A related API to this would be an API to switch the current tab.  Is there an API to switch the current tab?  I don't see anything relevant on https://neovim.io/doc/user/api.html#api-tabpage.  If not, I'd be willing to contribute this feature after this PR lands.

([context](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32893#issuecomment-2725997744))
Thanks!  The next API in the doc, `vim.api.nvim_get_current_win` is what I needed. 🚀

title: feat(api): add `nvim_open_tabpage`
